content: The "United States Marshals Service 225th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act" commemorates the establishment of the United States Marshals as the first Federal law enforcement officers in America under the Judiciary Act of September 24, 1789, signed into law by President George Washington. Washington nominated the first 11 Marshals on September 24, 1789. The United States Marshals Service was established in 1789 under the Judiciary Act, with the first 11 Marshals nominated by President George Washington. The remaining two Marshals were confirmed by the Senate on September 26, 1789. In 1969, the United States Marshals Service achieved Bureau status and has played a significant role in the nation's history, serving as a civil authority for all branches of government. Robert Forsyth, one of the original Marshals, was the first to be killed in the line of duty in 1794. The United States Marshals Service Commemorative Coin will honor the nation's oldest Federal law enforcement agency, established in 1789. The coin aims to bring attention to the agency's legacy and support national museums and charitable organizations through proceeds from sales. The coin specifications will commemorate the 225th anniversary. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins in commemoration of the 225th anniversary of the United States Marshals Service. The coins will have specific weights, diameters, and compositions. The coins minted under this Act will weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches, and be minted to the specifications for half dollar coins. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins will symbolize the 225 years of achievements of the United States Marshals Service, with inscriptions of the coin value. The $5 gold coins minted under this Act will bear inscriptions of the mint date "2015", years 1789 and 2014, and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The obverse will feature the United States Marshals Service Star, while the reverse will depict the sacrifice and service of the men and women of the United States. The $1 silver coins issued under this Act will bear images of the United States Marshals Service Star and depict the Marshals as the lawmen of the frontiers. The reverse of the coins will symbolize the Marshals' legendary status in America's cultural landscape. The design will include the Marshals Service motto "Justice, Integrity, Service". The half dollar clad coins issued under this Act will feature images emblematic of the United States Marshals Service and its history on the obverse, while the reverse will depict the Marshals' role in pivotal social issues in American history, emphasizing their ties to the United States Constitution. The half dollar coins will depict the United States Marshals Service's history and their role in pivotal social issues like the Whiskey Rebellion, slavery, inequality, and the struggle between labor and capital. The designs for coins issued under this Act will be selected based on realism and historical accuracy, reminiscent of the artwork from the "Golden Age of Coinage" in the early 20th Century. The Secretary, in consultation with the United States Marshals Service and the Commission of Fine Arts, will choose the designs, which will be reviewed by the Citizens Coin Advisory Committee. The coins minted under this Act will be issued in proof and uncirculated quality, with only one facility of the United States Mint allowed to strike each combination of denomination and quality. The Secretary can start issuing coins to the public from January 1, 2015, with a limited number available earlier for the 225th Anniversary celebration. Minting under this Act must cease by December 31, 2015. The sale price of the coins will be determined by the Secretary. The Secretary can sell coins at a price including face value, surcharge, and design costs. Prepaid orders are accepted with a discount. Surcharges for coins minted include $35 for gold, $10 for silver, and $3 for half dollar. The Secretary can sell coins with surcharges of $35 for gold, $10 for silver, and $3 for half dollar coins. Surcharges received are distributed to the U.S. Marshals Museum, National Center for Missing & Exploited Children, and Federal Law Enforcement Officers Association Foundation. Enforcement Officers Association Foundation receives financial assistance from surcharges on coins sold by the Secretary. The Enforcement Officers Association Foundation provides financial assistance to surviving family members of Federal law enforcement members killed in the line of duty, those who have become disabled, and employees and their families in select instances of severe trauma or financial loss where no other assistance is available. The Enforcement Officers Association Foundation provides financial assistance to law enforcement families in need, scholarships for students in the law enforcement field, and grants to charitable organizations. One third of the funds go to the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund for the construction of the National Law Enforcement Museum. All recipients are subject to audit requirements. No surcharge may be included for commemorative coins if it exceeds the limit set by the Act. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to ensure that the issuance of commemorative coins does not exceed the annual limit. Financial assurances are required to ensure no net cost to the government and that all costs related to designing and issuing the coins are recovered before funds are disbursed to recipients. The Secretary of the Treasury ensures that the issuance of commemorative coins does not exceed the annual limit. Costs related to designing and issuing the coins (expenses, marketing, and shipping) are recovered by the United States Treasury.
